The tech firms that run our lives are not as virtuous as they claim2012-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:43ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9HOW GoogleTURNED EVEL[...]Don't be fooled, says John Arlidge. The tech firms that run our lives are not as virtuous as they claimJohn Arlidge

In sunny places with bucolic names such as Mountain View and Menlo Park, the glistening headquarters of Google, Facebook and Apple seem to sweep you up off the pavement with the promise of a glimpse into the future - and a good time.

As the company's youthful bosses arrive each morning at their ecofriendly offices in their T-shirts and trainers, they like to imagine they are a cut above conventional business leaders.

Google's mission statement is "Don't be evil" and its founders, Larry Page, 39, and Sergey Brin, 38, say they want to make the world a better place. Facebook's freshly minted billionaire boss, Mark Zuckerberg, 28, claims he is dedicated to "openness, connecting and sharing".

Before his death last year Steve Jobs, Apple's chief executive, said: "Being the richest man in the cemetery doesn't matter. Saying we've done something wonderful, that's what matters."

The shine is coming off Silicon Valley's finest, however.

This week the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), Britain's data watchdog, announced it was reopening its investigation into Google's Street View cars, which travel around taking photographs to create the search engine's popular mapping service.

It has emerged that Googleprogrammed the vehicles to gather private data, including email, web searches and photographs, from unsecured home wi-fi networks. It also stands accused of trying to cover up what it had been doing.

European Union regulators are examining claims that Googleis abusing its dominance in the search business by ranking its own products higher up in results than those of its rivals. A similar case in the 1990s tarnished the reputation and hit the profits of Microsoft, then the world's most fearsome tech behemoth. The ICO's move comes as Apple faces criticism over its plans, revealed last week by The Sunday Times, for an answer to Street View: an even more intrusive 3-D service using militarygrade aerial camera satellites capable of revealing objects as small as 4in across.

Facebook is having a torrid time too. Shares in the world's most successful social network have fallen sharply since it floated on the Nasdaq in New York last month. To add to its woes, figures released last week showed its hitherto phenomenal growth is beginning to slow: in April, its site had 158m unique users, up only 5% on a year earlier, according to the research firm comScore - the lowest rise since it began tracking the data in 2008.

The new figures have fuelled the anger of many disgruntled small investors who are suing Facebook over claims that it had told bankers and a select group of investors that its growth was slowing before its float - but neglected to share the information with them.

The recent setbacks mean the bosses of the big tech firms will spend a lot less time talking to their flipflopwearing staff this summer and a lot more time talking to buttoned-up lawyers. Googlefaces fines if the ICO finds its Street View cars breached data protection laws. The company could also face a police investigation.

HOW did we fall out of love with these pillars of the new economy whose services and products have so quickly become central to our lives? The simple answer is that consumers and legislators alike have finally woken up to an uncomfortable truth: despite their laid-back image, these tech giants are just as corporate, money grabbing and venal as the old-school entrepreneurs they so disdain. As Rob Cox, a leading American technology writer, puts it: "Under the hoodies and the moral language lurk rapacious business people, robber barons, with the same profit motive that drives all businesses and a ruthlessness rivalling history's greatest industrial bullies."

The charge sheet against the big tech firms is long: as well as pinching the private data of unsuspecting homeowners, carrying out creepy aerial surveillance and ripping off investors, they also stand accused of violating privacy.

Each makes money by vacuuming up the digital footprint we leave online and using it to sell us advertisements or market products. Hardly a day passes without some new revelation of one of them taking a byte too far.

Googlerecently altered its computer code to circumvent the privacy settings in Apple's Safari web browser, used by hundreds of millions of people. Facebook has come under fire for allowing companies to turn users' "likes" into advertisements that are then sent to their own online friends.

Googleis accused of "looking the other way" on copyright. Newspapers and magazines say the search engine "steals" their content and uses it to sell lucrative advertisements. Like Google, Apple is under investigation for monopolistic practices. The US justice department is examining claims that the firm, along with several publishers, colluded to raise the price of electronic books.

Apple has also been condemned for using Chinese manufacturers with lousy working practices. Foxconn, the Chinese factory where Apple's iPhones are made, has been investigated for treating its workers so badly that many have committed suicide.

Worst of all, say critics, is the aggressive tax avoidance practised by the big three. Google, Facebook and Apple have each set up elaborate webs of overseas companies to funnel revenues away from high-tax economies, such as Britain and Germany, through tax havens such as the Cayman Islands. The complex arrangements allow them - legally - to slash their tax bills.

Google, for example paid just (EURO)2.3m in Irish corporation tax on a turnover of more than (EURO)10 billion in 2010. Facebook, a firm now worth more than $60 billion ((EURO)47 billion), paid only (EURO)250,000 in corporation tax in Ireland in the same year, despite having revenues of (EURO)250m.

At every step of the way the companies have resisted attempts to clip their wings and even allegedly frustrated investigations into their less savoury practices. In April, the US Federal Communications Commission said Googlehad "deliberately impeded and delayed" its inquiry into the Street View data collection.

The tech giants have fought bitterly against any restrictions on internet use, opposing government attempts to introduce filters to prevent children accessing pornographic or violent images and moves to limit cyber bullying. Such "catch-all" filters do not work, they insist.

Critics retort that the companies will not introduce filters because they would limit search results, reducing the adverts that could be sold.

Search enginedriven advertising is a $10 billion market. Put the charges together and some observers say tech firms are taking over from banks as the corporate villains of our times. "Technology is replacing banking and finance as the industry most likely to worry government and the public," Time magazine said recently.

Googlehas apologised for harvesting data. "We screwed up," said Eric Schmidt, its executive chairman. The firm denies that it engages in anti-competitive behaviour and insists it offers safe web searching to protect children.

Facebook rejects claims that it misled investors when it floated and says it is beefing up its privacy controls. Apple denies monopolistic practices, while Jobs's successor, Tim Cook, has visited Foxconn and ordered fresh checks on factory working conditions.

Understandably, the three also emphasise the positives: they have created the greatest explosion of democracy, access to information and ability to connect and communicate the world has ever seen - all of which has generated great wealth. This is undoubtedly true, yet there is a nagging doubt that, like the big banks before the financial crash, these titans of the new economy are woefully lightly regulated.

SOME people are trying to fight back. Authorities here and in America are trying to close loopholes to force the tech giants to pay more tax. Politicians are drawing up an online privacy "bill of rights". To protect copyright, two anti-piracy bills have been proposed in America.

Yet there is little evidence that such moves are working. Heavy lobbying by Silicon Valley, whose economic might makes it of vital importance to the American economy, has seen off proposed legislation.

Ironically, big tech's critics might find a solution in tech itself. Alarmed by the backlash against them, Google, Microsoft and Apple have indicated they might support the development of a "do not track" button in all web browsers. By flipping a switch, users could instruct websites not to monitor their online behaviour.

Independent tech firms are starting to offer consumers the chance to protect their data. SafetyWeb helps parents monitor their children's activities on social networking sites and is launching myID.com, a privacy protection service for adults.

Then there is the ultimate technological solution: switch off. Googleand Facebook know that if they lose the trust of their users they are only a few clicks away from extinction, such as AltaVista or Netscape. Apple has had more than enough brushes with corporate mortality to know its future is not guaranteed.

In the end it is you and me, the users, who have the real power over the big three. If we continue to log on, they will carry on growing - and doing whatever they like. If we turn against them or switch to a new operator whose products and values we prefer, they will die in a heartbeat. The choice is ours - at the click of a mouse.

'' UNDER THE HOODIES AND THE MORAL LANGUAGE LURK ROBBER BARONS

urn:contentItem:55X1-B8N1-DYVC-J562-00000-00HOW GOOGLE TURNED EVIL;Don't be fooled, says John Arlidge. The tech firms that run our lives are not as virtuous as they claim2012-06-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:43ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 18HOW GOOGLETURNED EVILDon't be fooled, says John Arlidge. The tech firms that run our lives are not as virtuous as they claimJohn Arlidge

In sunny places with bucolic names such as Mountain View and Menlo Park, the glistening headquarters of Google, Facebook and Apple seem to sweep you up off the pavement with the promise of a glimpse into the future - and a good time. As the firms' youthful bosses arrive each morning at their eco-friendly offices in their T-shirts and trainers, they like to imagine they are a cut above conventional business leaders.

Google's mission statement is "Don't be evil" and its founders, Larry Page, 39, and Sergey Brin, 38, say they want to make the world a better place. Facebook's freshly minted billionaire boss, Mark Zuckerberg, 28, claims he is dedicated to "openness, connecting and sharing". Before his death last year Steve Jobs, Apple's chief executive, said: "Being the richest man in the cemetery doesn't matter. Saying we've done something wonderful, that's what matters."

The shine is coming off Silicon Valley's finest, however.Last week the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), Britain's data watchdog, announced it was reopening its investigation into Google's Street View cars, which travel around taking photographs to create the search engine's popular mapping service.

It has emerged that Googleprogrammed the vehicles to gather private data, including email, web searches and photographs, from unsecured home wi-fi networks. It also stands accused of trying to cover up what it had been doing.

European Union regulators are examining claims that Googleis abusing its dominance in the search business by ranking its own products higher up in results than those of its rivals. A similar case in the 1990s tarnished the reputation and hit the profits of Microsoft, then the world's most fearsome tech behemoth.

The latest moves come as Apple faces criticism over its plans, revealed last week by The Sunday Times, for an answer to Street View: an even more intrusive 3-D service using military-grade aerial camera satellites capable of revealing objects as small as 4in across.

Facebook is having a torrid time, too. Shares in the world's most successful social network have fallen sharply since it floated on the Nasdaq in New York last month. To add to its woes, figures released last week showed its hitherto phenomenal growth is beginning to slow: in April, its site had 158m unique users, up only 5% on a year earlier, according to the research firm comScore - the lowest rise since it began tracking the data in 2008.

The new figures have fuelled the anger of many disgruntled small investors who are suing Facebook over claims that it had told bankers and a select group of investors that its growth was slowing before its float - but neglected to share the information with them.

The recent setbacks mean the bosses of the big tech firms will spend a lot less time talking to their flipflop-wearing staff this summer and a lot more time talking to buttonedup lawyers. Googlefaces fines if the ICO finds its Street View cars breached data protection laws. The company could also face a police investigation.

HOW did we fall out of love with these pillars of the new economy whose services and products have so quickly become central to our lives? The simple answer is that consumers and legislators alike have finally woken up to an uncomfortable truth: despite their laid-back image, these tech giants are just as corporate, money-grabbing and venal as the old-school businesses they so disdain.

As Rob Cox, a leading US technology writer, puts it: "Under the hoodies and the moral language lurk rapacious business people, robber barons, with the same profit motive that drives all businesses and a ruthlessness rivalling history's greatest industrial bullies."

The charge sheet against the big tech firms is long: as well as pinching the private data of unsuspecting homeowners, carrying out creepy aerial surveillance and ripping off investors, they also stand accused of violating privacy.

Each makes money by vacuuming up the digital footprint we leave online and using it to sell advertisements or market products. Hardly a day passes without some new revelation of one of them taking a byte too far.

Googlerecently altered its computer code to circumvent the privacy settings in Apple's Safari web browser, used by hundreds of millions of people. Facebook has come under fire for allowing companies to turn users' "likes" into advertisements that are then sent to their own online friends.

Googleis accused of "looking the other way" on copyright. Newspapers and magazines say the search engine "steals" their content and uses it to sell lucrative advertisements. Like Google, Apple is under investigation for monopolistic practices. The US justice department is examining claims that the firm, along with several publishers, colluded to raise the price of electronic books.

Apple has also been condemned for using Chinese manufacturers with lousy working practices. Foxconn, the Chinese factory where Apple's iPhones are made, has been investigated for treating its workers so badly that many have committed suicide.

Worst of all, say critics, is the aggressive tax avoidance practised by the big three. Google, Facebook and Apple have each set up elaborate webs of overseas companies to funnel revenues away from high-tax economies, such as Britain and Germany, through tax havens such as the Cayman Islands. The complex arrangements allow them - legally - to slash their tax bills.

Google, for example, paid just £1.2m in British corporation tax in 2010 on sales that topped £2.2 billion. Apple has stashed two-thirds of its $110 billion cash hoard overseas, out of the reach of the American taxman. Facebook, now worth more than $60 billion, paid a staggeringly low £397,000 in British corporation tax in 2010.

At every step of the way the companies have resisted attempts to clip their wings and even allegedly frustrated investigations into their less savoury practices. In April the US Federal Communications Commission said Googlehad "deliberately impeded and delayed" its inquiry into the Street View data collection.

The tech giants have fought bitterly against any restrictions on internet use, opposing government attempts to introduce filters to prevent children accessing pornographic or violent images and moves to limit cyber bullying.Such "catch-all" filters do not work, they insist.

Critics retort that the companies will not introduce filters because they would limit search results, reducing the adverts that could be sold. Search engine-driven advertising is a $10 billion market. Put the charges together and some observers say tech firms are taking over from banks as the corporate villains of our times. "Technology is replacing banking and finance as the industry most likely to worry government and the public," Time magazine said recently.

Googlehas apologised for harvesting data. "We screwed up," said Eric Schmidt, its executive chairman. The firm denies that it engages in anti-competitive behaviour and insists it offers safe web searching to protect children. Facebook rejects claims that it misled investors when it floated and says it is beefing up its privacy controls. Apple denies monopolistic practices, while Jobs's successor, Tim Cook, has visited Foxconn and ordered fresh checks on factory working conditions.

Understandably, the three also emphasise the positives: they have created the greatest explosion of democracy, access to information and ability to connect and communicate that the world has ever seen - all of which has generated great wealth.

This is undoubtedly true yet there is a nagging doubt that, like the big banks before the financial crash, these titans of the new economy are woefully lightly regulated.

If an airline does something as simple and annoying as lose our luggage, we get compensation.If a web operator pinches our data and then tries to cover its tracks, we get nothing, even though data theft can lead to identity theft. "The web is largely unregulated," said Professor Peter Sommer, a Londonbased cyber expert.

SOME people are trying to fight back. Authorities here and in America are attempting to close loopholes to force the tech giants to pay more tax. Politicians are drawing up an online privacy "bill of rights". To protect copyright, two antipiracy bills have been proposed in the United States.

Yet there is little evidence that such moves are working. Heavy lobbying by Silicon Valley, whose economic might makes it of vital importance to the American economy, has seen off proposed legislation. While some users might make use of new privacy codes, most of us are so wedded to our iPads, smartphones and Facebook that we cannot imagine life without them and will not give them up - regardless of how the companies which own them behave. This article was prepared using Google's search engine and its suite of online word-processing products.

Ironically, big tech's critics might find a solution in tech itself. Alarmed by the backlash against them, Google, Microsoft and Apple have indicated they might support the development of a "do not track" button in all web browsers. By flipping a switch, users could instruct websites not to monitor their online behaviour.

Independent tech firms are starting to offer consumers the chance to protect their data. SafetyWeb helps parents monitor their children's activities on social networking sites and is launching myID.com, a privacy protection service for adults. Other firms offer consumers the chance to profit from their personal information: the London-based Allow Ltd gathers our data and lets us sell it to firms we approve of - in return for a small fee.

Then there is the ultimate technological solution: switch off. Googleand Facebook know that if they lose the trust of their users they are only a few clicks away from extinction, such as AltaVista or Netscape. Apple has had more than enough brushes with corporate mortality to know its future is not guaranteed.

In the end it is you and me, the users, who have the real power over the big three. If we continue to log on they will carry on growing - and doing whatever they like. If we turn against them or switch to a new operator whose products and values we prefer, they will die in a heartbeat. The choice is ours - at the click of a mouse.

'' UNDER THE HOODIES AND THE MORAL LANGUAGE LURK ROBBER BARONS

The economic price paid by women entrepreneurs during the coronavirus pandemic is far higher than that paid by their male counterparts. Because entrepreneurs are increasingly women, post-pandemic economic recovery is threatened. The share of women-owned businesses soared from 4.6% in 1972 to 42% in 2019, according to the American Express 2019 State of Women-Owned Businesses .* According to the 2019–2020 Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM), the benefits to society of entrepreneurship are better understood and appreciated. Community Revival in the Wake of Disaster Lessons in Local Entrepreneurship , finds that entrepreneurs drive economic recovery and help communities rebound after disasters. Catastrophic events such as a major hurricane, earthquake, flood, recession, or pandemic destroy, but, in their wake, entrepreneurs create. Entrepreneurs—more and more of them women—help communities survive and bounce back from destructive events. Covid-19 Exposes Existing Inequities For Women While men are still more likely to engage in Total Entrepreneurial Activity (TEA), the gender gap narrowed between 2018 and 2019 in the United States: the ratio was 7.5 to 10 and 9 to 10 respectively, according to GEM. "TEA includes people who are thinking about starting a business, are in the process of starting a business, or have started a business in the past three years," said Amanda Elam, GEM researcher and Diana Research Fellow, Diana International Research Institute at Babson College. Women held about 60% of the jobs that have been lost . "I think we should go ahead and call this a 'shecession,'" said C. Nicole Mason, president and chief executive of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in a New York Times article. Necessity entrepreneurship was dramatically higher for women than men during the 2007-2008 recession, according to GEM. This trend is even more likely during a shecession. Necessity entrepreneurs cannot find quality employment or are unemployed, so their only viable employment option is to start a business. Women are more likely to leave their jobs because of childcare issues: 14% of women considered quitting their jobs because of the coronavirus pandemic, according to a survey by Syndio, a pay-equity software company. More women may turn to entrepreneurship for flexibility to accommodate childcare issues. Necessity and flexibility entrepreneurs tend to be sidepreneurs . These part-time businesses are smaller than full-time businesses. Their founders are more likely to return to the workforce when they can. Opportunity entrepreneurs see possibilities in the market that they want to exploit. They are more likely to enter the market in good economic times than in bad. After the 2007-2008 financial crisis, opportunity entrepreneurship took a back seat to necessity entrepreneurship. This pattern is likely to repeat itself now and be even more extreme. However, even in bad times, opportunity does exist. Fear of failure is more likely to hold women back from starting a business than men, commented Elam. "This could be because women are concerned that if they fail, they don't have a plan B." Women of Color Face Greater Challenges Yet Increasingly Are Becoming Entrepreneurs Women represent 51% of the adult population in the United States, but 42% of all business owners , and only 20% of employer businesses**. Women of color represent 40% of all women , 89% of all net new women-owned businesses , but only 24% of employer women-owned businesses**. Structural differences in personal wealth , business experience , and networks , as well as different entrepreneurial motivations and cultural expectations —women do most of the household chores and are more likely to be caregivers—result in an under representation of women, especially among employer**, million-dollar-plus**, and venture-backed businesses . The Covid-19 Crisis shuttered small businesses unequally. Between February to April 2020, black-owned businesses declined by 41% according to The Impact of Covid-19 on Small Business Owners: Evidence of Early Stage Losses from the April 2020 Current Population Survey . Immigrant-owned businesses dropped by 36%, Hispanic owned businesses by 32%, Asian-owned businesses by 26%, and women-owned businesses by 25%. White-owned businesses fell only 17%. The study didn't analyze minority-women-owned businesses. However, because minority-women-owned businesses are in the sectors that were most impacted by lock-down orders—personal care, retail, and restaurants—and their businesses tend to be smaller than men’s, their numbers may have shrunk even more. With Covid-19 cases surging throughout the United States, and looming lock downs, even if only partial, will continue to shock the economy in waves. The pandemic will have severe consequences on small businesses, especially those owned by women of color. Supporting Women Entrepreneurs There are encouraging signs that federal, state, and local governments, as well as large corporations are helping small businesses recover. They have rallied to support small businesses by providing grants, forgivable loans, and low-cost loans. But more can be done. Entrepreneurial Ecosystem Conditions and Gendered National-Level Entrepreneurial Activity: a 14-year panel study of GEM finds women’s entrepreneurship thrives when there is supportive government policy towards entrepreneurship, minimal commercial and legal infrastructure, and a normative culture that supports entrepreneurship. According to GEM, the United States is weakest at: Government entrepreneurial programs: The presence and quality of programs directly assisting small businesses at all levels of government (national, regional, municipal). For example, the federal government should increase funding to SBA Women's Business Center (or local programs), which provide entrepreneurial training, access to capital, access to markets through government and corporate supplier programs, as well as coaching and mentorship. R & D transfer: National research and development that leads to new commercial opportunities and is available to small businesses. Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) and Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) programs are federal grant programs that provide needed investment in America's most innovative small businesses. Only a tiny percentage of funds from these programs go to female founders. Partnering with organizations such as Springboard Enterprises’ Women's Health Innovation Coalition which I wrote about last week would improve the odds. The female founded companies involved in the initiative are likely to take advantage of SBIR and STTR grants. Government policies—Support and Relevance: The extent to which public policies support entrepreneurship. Whether it is local, state, or federal, all levels of government should mandate increased spending with diverse small businesses. The benefits to government agencies include: access to innovative products/services; increase in competition, resulting in better prices and service levels; highlight their commitment to diversity and inclusion, and a shared and durable prosperity; and help them be flexible, agile, and resilient. A Gendered Look at Entrepreneurship Ecosystems finds support for child care would facilitate and encourage more women to participate in entrepreneurship. Despite women entrepreneurs being ready, willing, and able to receive loans, access to them is a challenge. Tracking small business loans by gender, race and ethnicity would hold lenders accountable. Having women as venture capital decision makers, improves the odds for female founders getting funding. While more and more women are starting venture funds, these funds tend to be small. The Small Business Investment Company (SBIC) should rethink it model to encourage and approve the new wave of female founded funds for this program. Emerging manager programs need to be rethought to enable smaller funds to qualify. Internal market burdens or entry regulations: The burdens include entry of new and growing firms in the market and the effectiveness of antitrust legislation. For example, big tech firms such as Apple, Amazon, Facebook, and Google, have been accused by smaller rivals of anti-competitive behavior and have asked Congress for protection. Congress should act. What resources will help your business survive the pandemic?

urn:contentItem:5HBT-9B01-JCBD-D333-00000-00HOW GREEDY PHONE GIANTS HIKE OUR BILLS EVERY 16 DAYS2015-11-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:43ZLexisNexisHOW GREEDY PHONE GIANTS HIKE OUR BILLS EVERY 16 DAYS

... AND STILL YOUR INTERNET WON'T BE AS FAST AS THEY PROMISE

BY HOLLY BLACK

TODAY, Money Mail exposes how Britain's biggest telecoms firms are hitting customers with a price rise every 16 days while misleading them about internet speeds and changes to their contracts.

Our investigation lays bare how households are paying more than £1,000 a year for deals which cost them £750 just four years ago.

At the weekend, the Government outlined plans to make fast broadband a legal right as electricity or gas already is for all homeowners in the UK.

But our probe shows that if this is to happen by 2020, the big tech firms have a long way to go, because while costs have soared, service for millions of homeowners remains diabolical.

Our investigation highlights how:

* the big four' firms have hiked prices 90 times in four years;

* line rental has increased by as much as 54 pc;

* just one-in-six homes gets their advertised broadband speed at peak times;

* complaints about telecoms firms are soaring;

* customers are paying excessive charges because firms refuse to tell them when their contract comes to an end;

* BT customers have been lured in to paying for sport TV channels they don't want;

* Sky has been automatically making customers pay for a phone package they don't need;

* Households are waiting days to get phonelines fixed because of a bitter industry row.

the costs THAT KEEP ON SOARING

Over the past four years, the big four providers BT, Sky, TalkTalk and Virgin have hiked prices on 90 separate occasions, according to figures compiled for Money Mail by comparison site Simplify Digital. There is growing anger from consumers about landline costs, which they see as unnecessary. Many modern families use mobile phones rather than a landline, and so don't want the latter.

But they're over a barrel because they can't have a broadband service from the major providers without paying for landline. This allows the telecoms firms to artificially lower the price of their internet deals while sneakily hiking landline prices.

Virgin Media, however, does allow customers to have its cable-based TV and internet service without paying for a landline.

Some 31 of the price rises were by Sky. BT had 17, with seven of these increases to its line rental. Virgin Media made 29 price increases, and TalkTalk 13. In total, it equates to one price rise every 16 days.

In four years, Sky's line rental has leapt from £11.25 a month to £17.40 a rise of 54 pc.

BT's has jumped from £13.60 to £17.99, Virgin's from £11.99 to £16.99, and TalkTalk's from £14.95 to £17.70.

Frequently, an individual firm has increased its charges twice inside six months.

But it's not just the hike in costs that annoy customers, it's the tricks firms use. Sky recently told customers that monthly line rental would increase from £16.40 to £17.40 from December 1.

The letter it sent customers says they'll be put on the best-value package based on how they use its service, or the nearest equivalent to what they currently have.

But some customers who don't use their landline were put on to a package which gives free evening and weekend calls and costs an additional £4 per month.

However, there is a tariff which has no additional monthly cost but instead charges for every landline call a customer makes. For many households who don't use their landline, this is the perfect option, but they have been automatically dumped on to the more expensive deal.

BT has also angered customers over the way it charges for its BT Sport channels.

In May 2013, it heralded free BT Sport which now offers a mix of Champions League and Premier League football, plus other sports for those with its broadband packages.

However, the telecoms giant brought the free deal to an end earlier this year. Instead, it said the service would now cost £5 a month. But customers had to opt out of the new £5-a-month charge if they wanted to avoid it. This left up to five million facing a steep rise in bills from August.

Some have complained they weren't clearly told about the change or didn't even realise they'd been charged. Others who did notice the new fee have struggled to cancel BT Sport.

Furious Money Mail readers Petula Peel and Roy Hancock spent hours on the phone and writing letters trying to stop the extra monthly payment.

Petula, from Royston, Hertfordshire, says: We've been in dispute about the extra BT Sport from the start, and found the bills very confusing. It was as though BT didn't want us to realise we were paying extra for a sports add-on we don't want.'

Fed up with poor service, the couple customers of 40 years' standing have now joined Sky.

Another customer, Hugh Froggatt, brands the £5-a-month rise as a stealth charge.

He says: The charge for BT Sport was a service I never asked for, never used and did not realise I had. It will earn BT a tidy windfall from unsuspecting customers.'

Another reader branded it a form of inertia selling I find reprehensible'.

As well as price hikes, customers are seeing perks axed.

TalkTalk is removing its speedy payment discount from December 1. Until now, customers who paid by direct debit or within 24 hours of receiving a bill by email have been given 10 pc off of their bill. The discount was already reduced from 15 pc last year.

Those who want to switch to a cheaper deal also face problems. Regulator Ofcom has already told firms they should tell customers when contracts come to an end, so people know when to look for a cheaper deal. At the moment, though, this rarely happens.

Trying to compare packages between the major providers is also nigh-on impossible. Research by Broadband Choices shows that the total cost of landline and broadband from some of the major providers is up to five times as much as the advertised price. And if you stay loyal to your provider, you're punished with even higher prices.

And not all customers can get all services. Virgin cables connect to only 13.6 million homes in the country. Some people can't get Sky because their property can't be fitted with a satellite dish. And even BT does not offer its superfast broadband to all homes across the country.

Once you've decided what to buy, there can be additional charges for the technology that helps you get your internet and TV service, such as routers and boxes.

Research by uSwitch has found that those who stick with their provider after their initial deal are paying £151 a year more than they should.

HOMES HIT

THE GREAT GO-SLOW

Once you have broadband, it's likely it will be slower than you had hoped.

The speed and the amount of internet you can download are crucial to many households these days particularly those who enjoy video games, and anyone who uses internet television services such as Netflix.

A survey by consumer association Which? found 90 pc of consumers rate speed as an important factor when they picked an internet provider.

Despite this, Which? found that 15.4 million homes don't get the advertised speed. The figures are even worse in peak hours: it is estimated just 15 pc are able to get the maximum advertised speed.

Overall, fewer than one-in-three households in towns and cities is capable of getting the maximum speed; in rural areas just 4pc of homes are able to.

Part of the reason for this go-slow is that the wires which provide the internet service aren't capable of delivering the highest speeds.

To get a top service you need fibre optic cables. But only a fifth of homes in the countryside are connected to these compared with three-quarters of those in urban areas.

And even where there are fibre optic cables, these often don't run straight to your front door. Many superfast cables run only to the exchange at the end of your road. From there, copper wires which are much slower run the signal to your house.

If fibre cables are laid right the way to your home, it's possible to get speeds of up to 330 Mb per second that would mean an HD film could be downloaded in under 20 seconds. But if you just have copper wires running to your house, the maximum it would be theoretically possible to get is 80 Mb.

Yet despite providers boasting that they can produce these speeds, Ofcom research shows the typical speed achieved across the country is just 23 Mb.

Again, even this can be theoretical for homes in built-up areas where lots of households all want to use the internet at the same time.

So at peak times, typically at weekends and between 8pm and 10pm on weekday evenings, just one in 25 of TalkTalk's customers received the maximum advertised speed of 17 Mb during Which? testing.

A fifth of its customers achieved an average speed of only 5 Mb half that of Ofcom's recommended minimum speed.

Sky, BT and Plusnet customers typically achieved speeds of 10 Mb during the research. And fewer than one in five of their customers managed to get the advertised speed.

Virgin Media offers a rare glimmer of hope to internet users who want to get the fastest speeds. Research found that 98 pc of its customers get the advertised speed in off-peak hours, while more than half will get these speeds at peak times.

So how do the firms get away with advertising speeds which are just not achievable?

It is because internet providers need only to ensure 10 pc of their customers can get a certain speed. Hit this target and they can boast that there speeds up to' that level.

The requirement on other sectors are much more onerous. For example, loan and credit card firms cannot advertise a rate unless it is available to at least 51 pc of applicants.

Virgin has branded internet advertising rules outdated and misleading'.

While prices rise and consumers get frustrated by their plodding broadband speed, complaints are sky-high.

In June, Ofcom warned telecoms firms to improve service. In particular, it says people still find it too difficult to change provider and cancel contracts.

Ofcom data shows that some of the biggest firms are generating complaints which are way over the industry average of 16 per 100,000 customers.

TalkTalk received 27 complaints per 100,000 customers. BT and Plusnet received 22 and 20 complaints respectively. Virgin Media saw just seven complaints, and Sky had the fewest at just five for every 100,000 of its broadband customers.

But in August the regulator announced it would be investigating Sky over concerns that it was ignoring customers' cancellation requests or making it difficult for them to leave their contract.

The communications watchdog also introduced a strengthened code of practice on broadband speeds, allowing customers to exit a contract if speeds fall below acceptable levels.

Meanwhile, many providers say they are limited in how much they can improve their services because BT controls the network which runs all the wires this is run by a BT-owned company called Openreach.

Rival internet providers either pay a fee to use Openreach equipment and run their service through that, or install their own equipment in Openreach exchanges and rent a copper line to run to customers' homes.

Sky is petitioning Ofcom to change this system, arguing that they rely on it to provide a service to customers and it is wrong that they have no control over it.

BT argues that disrupting the status quo would delay improvements. Meanwhile, as these big firms bicker, service continues to be disrupted for ordinary consumers.

A Virgin spokesman says: Virgin is the only widely available provider to consistently deliver its advertised speeds, let alone exceed them.

This is because we have our own fibre-optic broadband network while other providers are reliant on BT's copper cable.'

A TalkTalk spokesman says: TalkTalk is the only provider to offer unlimited broadband as standard on every single package, with no hidden charges or download caps. We provide customers with a speed estimate before they sign a contract with us.'

A BT spokesman says: In common with the rest of the industry, BT's standard line rental has increased since 2008, but that stat only tells part of the story. We're very clear that customers should not rely on headline claims for broadband speeds but use the personal speed quote we give them at the point of sale, which is based on their own line.

If they aren't happy with this personalised speed, they can decide not to buy from us. If they are happy with the speed, but find they don't achieve it, we allow them to end their contracts in line with the Ofcom code of practice.'

A Sky spokesman says: Our line rental price remains competitive and we continue to invest in our service. When customers sign up to broadband we estimate the speed they can expect, and they can cancel their broadband if we're unable to deliver a guaranteed minimum.'

Another reader branded it 'a form of inertia selling I find reprehensible'.

As well as price hikes, customers are seeing perks axed.

TalkTalk is removing its speedy payment discount from December 1. Until now, customers who paid by direct debit or within 24 hours of receiving a bill by email have been given 10 per cent off of their bill. The discount was already reduced from 15 per cent last year.

Research by uSwitch has found that those who stick with their provider after their initial deal are paying £151 a year more than they should.

Overall, fewer than one-in-three households in towns and cities is capable of getting the maximum speed; in rural areas just 4 per cent of homes are able to.

Part of the reason for this go-slow is that the wires which provide the internet service aren't capable of delivering the highest speeds.

To get a top service you need fibre optic cables. But only a fifth of homes in the countryside are connected to these compared with three-quarters of those in urban areas.

And even where there are fibre optic cables, these often don't run straight to your front door. Many superfast cables run only to the exchange at the end of your road. From there, copper wires - which are much slower - run the signal to your house.

If fibre cables are laid right the way to your home, it's possible to get speeds of up to 330 Mb per second - that would mean an HD film could be downloaded in under 20 seconds.

It is because internet providers need only to ensure 10 per cent of their customers can get a certain speed. Hit this target and they can boast that there speeds 'up to' that level.

Meanwhile, many providers say they are limited in how much they can improve their services because BT controls the network which runs all the wires - this is run by a BT-owned company called Openreach.

Rival internet providers either pay a fee to use Openreach equipment and run their service through that, or install their own equipment in Openreach exchanges and rent a copper line to run to customers' homes.

Sky is petitioning Ofcom to change this system, arguing that they rely on it to provide a service to customers and it is wrong that they have no control over it.

BT argues that disrupting the status quo would delay improvements. Meanwhile, as these big firms bicker, service continues to be disrupted for ordinary consumers.

A Virgin spokesman says: 'Virgin is the only widely available provider to consistently deliver its advertised speeds, let alone exceed them.

'This is because we have our own fibre-optic broadband network while other providers are reliant on BT's copper cable.'

A TalkTalk spokesman says: 'TalkTalk is the only provider to offer unlimited broadband as standard on every single package, with no hidden charges or download caps. We provide customers with a speed estimate before they sign a contract with us.'

A BT spokesman says: 'In common with the rest of the industry, BT's standard line rental has increased since 2008, but that stat only tells part of the story. 'If they aren't happy with this personalised speed, they can decide not to buy from us. If they are happy with the speed, but find they don't achieve it, we allow them to end their contracts in line with the Ofcom code of practice.'

A Sky spokesman says: 'Our line rental price remains competitive and we continue to invest in our service. When customers sign up to broadband we estimate the speed they can expect, and they can cancel their broadband if we're unable to deliver a guaranteed minimum.'

Money Mail has exposed how Britain's biggest telecoms firms are hitting customers with a price rise every 16 days while misleading them about internet speeds and changes to their contracts.

Our investigation lays bare how households are paying more than £1,000 a year for deals which cost them £750 just four years ago.

At the weekend, the Government outlined plans to make fast broadband a legal right - as electricity or gas already is - for all homeowners in the UK.

The 'big four' firms have hiked prices 90 times in four years

Line rental has increased by as much as 54 per cent

Complaints about telecoms firms are soaring

Customers are paying excessive charges because firms refuse to tell them when their contract comes to an end;

BT customers have been lured in to paying for sport TV channels they don't want

The costs that keep on soaring 

Over the past four years, the big four providers - BT, Sky, TalkTalk and Virgin - have hiked prices on 90 separate occasions, according to figures compiled for Money Mail by comparison site Simplify Digital. 

There is growing anger from consumers about landline costs, which they see as unnecessary. Many modern families use mobile phones rather than a landline, and so don't want the latter.

But they're over a barrel because they can't have a broadband service from the major providers without paying for landline. This allows the telecoms firms to artificially lower the price of their internet deals - while sneakily hiking landline prices.

Virgin Media, however, does allow customers to have its cable-based TV and internet service without paying for a landline.

Some 31 of the price rises were by Sky. 

BT had 17, with seven of these increases to its line rental. 

Virgin Media made 29 price increases, and TalkTalk 13. 

In total, it equates to one price rise every 16 days.

In four years, Sky's line rental has leapt from £11.25 a month to £17.40 - a rise of 54 per cent.

BT's has jumped from £13.60 to £17.99, Virgin's from £11.99 to £16.99, and TalkTalk's from £14.95 to £17.70.

Frequently, an individual firm has increased its charges twice inside six months.

The tricks used to bump up bills 

But it's not just the hike in costs that annoy customers, it's the tricks firms use. Sky recently told customers that monthly line rental would increase from £16.40 to £17.40 from December 1.

The letter it sent customers says they'll be put on the best-value package based on how they use its service, or the nearest equivalent to what they currently have.

But some customers who don't use their landline were put on to a package which gives free evening and weekend calls and costs an additional £4 per month.

However, there is a tariff which has no additional monthly cost - but instead charges for every landline call a customer makes. 

For many households who don't use their landline, this is the perfect option, but they have been automatically dumped on to the more expensive deal.

BT has also angered customers over the way it charges for its BT Sport channels.

In May 2013, it heralded free BT Sport - which now offers a mix of Champions League and Premier League football, plus other sports - for those with its broadband packages.

However, the telecoms giant brought the free deal to an end earlier this year. Instead, it said the service would now cost £5 a month. 

But customers had to opt out of the new £5-a-month charge if they wanted to avoid it. This left up to five million facing a steep rise in bills from August.

Some have complained they weren't clearly told about the change or didn't even realise they'd been charged. Others who did notice the new fee have struggled to cancel BT Sport.

He says: 'The charge for BT Sport was a service I never asked for, never used and did not realise I had. It will earn BT a tidy windfall from unsuspecting customers.'

Another reader branded it 'a form of inertia selling I find reprehensible'.

As well as price hikes, customers are seeing perks axed.

TalkTalk is removing its speedy payment discount from December 1. Until now, customers who paid by direct debit or within 24 hours of receiving a bill by email have been given 10 per cent off of their bill. The discount was already reduced from 15 per cent last year.

Those who want to switch to a cheaper deal also face problems. Regulator Ofcom has already told firms they should tell customers when contracts come to an end, so people know when to look for a cheaper deal. At the moment, though, this rarely happens.

Trying to compare packages between the major providers is also nigh-on impossible. Research by Broadband Choices shows that the total cost of landline and broadband from some of the major providers is up to five times as much as the advertised price.

Research by uSwitch has found that those who stick with their provider after their initial deal are paying £151 a year more than they should.

So how do the firms get away with advertising speeds which are just not achievable?

It is because internet providers need only to ensure 10 per cent of their customers can get a certain speed. Hit this target and they can boast that there speeds 'up to' that level.

The requirement on other sectors are much more onerous. For example, loan and credit card firms cannot advertise a rate unless it is available to at least 51 per cent of applicants.

Virgin has branded internet advertising rules 'outdated and misleading'.

Why complaints can be ignored 

While prices rise and consumers get frustrated by their plodding broadband speed, complaints are sky-high.

In June, Ofcom warned telecoms firms to improve service. In particular, it says people still find it too difficult to change provider and cancel contracts.

Ofcom data shows that some of the biggest firms are generating complaints which are way over the industry average of 16 per 100,000 customers.

TalkTalk received 27 complaints per 100,000 customers. BT and Plusnet received 22 and 20 complaints respectively. Virgin Media saw just seven complaints, and Sky had the fewest at just five for every 100,000 of its broadband customers.

But in August the regulator announced it would be investigating Sky over concerns that it was ignoring customers' cancellation requests or making it difficult for them to leave their contract.

Meanwhile, many providers say they are limited in how much they can improve their services because BT controls the network which runs all the wires - this is run by a BT-owned company called Openreach.

Sky is petitioning Ofcom to change this system, arguing that they rely on it to provide a service to customers and it is wrong that they have no control over it.

BT argues that disrupting the status quo would delay improvements. Meanwhile, as these big firms bicker, service continues to be disrupted for ordinary consumers.

A Virgin spokesman says: 'Virgin is the only widely available provider to consistently deliver its advertised speeds, let alone exceed them.

'This is because we have our own fibre-optic broadband network while other providers are reliant on BT's copper cable.'

A TalkTalk spokesman says: 'TalkTalk is the only provider to offer unlimited broadband as standard on every single package, with no hidden charges or download caps. We provide customers with a speed estimate before they sign a contract with us.'

A BT spokesman says: 'In common with the rest of the industry, BT's standard line rental has increased since 2008, but that stat only tells part of the story. We're very clear that customers should not rely on headline claims for broadband speeds but use the personal speed quote we give them at the point of sale, which is based on their own line.

'If they aren't happy with this personalised speed, they can decide not to buy from us. If they are happy with the speed, but find they don't achieve it, we allow them to end their contracts in line with the Ofcom code of practice.'

A Sky spokesman says: 'Our line rental price remains competitive and we continue to invest in our service. When customers sign up to broadband we estimate the speed they can expect, and they can cancel their broadband if we're unable to deliver a guaranteed minimum.'

TalkTalk received 27 complaints per 100,000 customers. BT and Plusnet received 22 and 20 complaints respectively. Virgin Media saw just seven complaints, and Sky had the fewest at just five for every 100,000 of its broadband customers.

But in August the regulator announced it would be investigating Sky over concerns that it was ignoring customers' cancellation requests or making it difficult for them to leave their contract.

The communications watchdog also introduced a strengthened code of practice on broadband speeds, allowing customers to exit a contract if speeds fall below acceptable levels.

Meanwhile, many providers say they are limited in how much they can improve their services because BT controls the network which runs all the wires - this is run by a BT-owned company called Openreach.

Rival internet providers either pay a fee to use Openreach equipment and run their service through that, or install their own equipment in Openreach exchanges and rent a copper line to run to customers' homes.

Sky is petitioning Ofcom to change this system, arguing that they rely on it to provide a service to customers and it is wrong that they have no control over it.

BT argues that disrupting the status quo would delay improvements. Meanwhile, as these big firms bicker, service continues to be disrupted for ordinary consumers.

A Virgin spokesman says: 'Virgin is the only widely available provider to consistently deliver its advertised speeds, let alone exceed them.

'This is because we have our own fibre-optic broadband network while other providers are reliant on BT's copper cable.'

A TalkTalk spokesman says: 'TalkTalk is the only provider to offer unlimited broadband as standard on every single package, with no hidden charges or download caps. We provide customers with a speed estimate before they sign a contract with us.'

A BT spokesman says: 'In common with the rest of the industry, BT's standard line rental has increased since 2008, but that stat only tells part of the story. We're very clear that customers should not rely on headline claims for broadband speeds but use the personal speed quote we give them at the point of sale, which is based on their own line.

'If they aren't happy with this personalised speed, they can decide not to buy from us. If they are happy with the speed, but find they don't achieve it, we allow them to end their contracts in line with the Ofcom code of practice.'

A Sky spokesman says: 'Our line rental price remains competitive and we continue to invest in our service. When customers sign up to broadband we estimate the speed they can expect, and they can cancel their broadband if we're unable to deliver a guaranteed minimum.'

urn:contentItem:5HC9-XB91-JCJY-G2R5-00000-00How greedy phone giants hike our bills every 18 days... but your internet still won't be as fast as they promise2015-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:43ZLexisNexisBILLSHow greedy phone giants hike our bills every 18 days... but your internet still won't be as fast as they promiseHOLLY BLACK FOR THE DAILY MAIL

The 'big four' firms have hiked prices 80 times in four years

L ine rental has increased by as much as 54 per cent 

BT customers lured into paying for sport TV channels they didn't want

Sky making customers pay for a phone package they didn't need

Money Mail has exposed how Britain's biggest telecoms firms are hitting customers with a price rise every 18 days while misleading them about internet speeds and changes to their contracts.

Our investigation lays bare how households are paying more than £1,000 a year for deals which cost them £750 just four years ago.

At the weekend, the Government outlined plans to make fast broadband a legal right - as electricity or gas already is - for all homeowners in the UK.

But our probe shows that if this is to happen by 2020, the big tech firms have a long way to go, because while costs have soared, service for millions of homeowners remains diabolical.

The investigation highlights how:

The 'big four' firms have hiked prices 80 times in four years

Line rental has increased by as much as 54 per cent

Complaints about telecoms firms are soaring

Customers are paying excessive charges because firms refuse to tell them when their contract comes to an end;

BT customers have been lured in to paying for sport TV channels they don't want

Sky has been automatically making customers pay for a phone package they don't need

Households are waiting days to get phonelines fixed because of a bitter industry row

The costs that keep on soaring 

Over the past four years, the big four providers - BT, Sky, TalkTalk and Virgin - have hiked prices on 90 separate occasions, according to figures compiled for Money Mail by comparison site Simplify Digital. 

There is growing anger from consumers about landline costs, which they see as unnecessary. Many modern families use mobile phones rather than a landline, and so don't want the latter.

But they're over a barrel because they can't have a broadband service from the major providers without paying for landline. This allows the telecoms firms to artificially lower the price of their internet deals - while sneakily hiking landline prices.

Virgin Media, however, does allow customers to have its cable-based TV and internet service without paying for a landline.

Some 31 of the price changes were by Sky.

BT had 17, with seven of these increases to its line rental. 

Virgin Media made 29 price changes, and TalkTalk 13.

In total, it equates to one price rise every 16 days.

In four years, Sky's line rental has leapt from £11.25 a month to £17.40 - a rise of 54 per cent.

BT's has jumped from £13.60 to £17.99, Virgin's from £11.99 to £16.99, and TalkTalk's from £14.95 to £17.70.

Frequently, an individual firm has increased its charges twice inside six months.

The tricks used to bump up bills 

But it's not just the hike in costs that annoy customers, it's the tricks firms use. Sky recently told customers that monthly line rental would increase from £16.40 to £17.40 from December 1.

The letter it sent customers says they'll be put on the best-value package based on how they use its service, or the nearest equivalent to what they currently have.

But some customers who don't use their landline were put on to a package which gives free evening and weekend calls and costs an additional £4 per month.

However, there is a tariff which has no additional monthly cost - but instead charges for every landline call a customer makes. 

For many households who don't use their landline, this is the perfect option, but they have been automatically dumped on to the more expensive deal.

BT has also angered customers over the way it charges for its BT Sport channels.

In May 2013, it heralded free BT Sport - which now offers a mix of Champions League and Premier League football, plus other sports - for those with its broadband packages.

However, the telecoms giant brought the free deal to an end earlier this year. Instead, it said the service would now cost £5 a month. 

But customers had to opt out of the new £5-a-month charge if they wanted to avoid it. This left up to five million facing a steep rise in bills from August.

Some have complained they weren't clearly told about the change or didn't even realise they'd been charged. Others who did notice the new fee have struggled to cancel BT Sport.

We spent hours trying to stop our BT Sport payment 

Furious Money Mail readers Petula Peel and Roy Hancock spent hours on the phone and writing letters trying to stop the extra monthly payment.

Petula, from Royston, Hertfordshire, says: 'We've been in dispute about the extra BT Sport from the start, and found the bills very confusing. It was as though BT didn't want us to realise we were paying extra for a sports add-on we don't want.'

Fed up with poor service, the couple - customers of 40 years' standing - have now joined Sky.

Another customer, Hugh Froggatt, brands the £5-a-month rise as a stealth charge.

He says: 'The charge for BT Sport was a service I never asked for, never used and did not realise I had. It will earn BT a tidy windfall from unsuspecting customers.'

Another reader branded it 'a form of inertia selling I find reprehensible'.

Extra charges, axed perks and difficulty switching 

As well as price hikes, customers are seeing perks axed.

TalkTalk is removing its speedy payment discount from December 1. Until now, customers who paid by direct debit or within 24 hours of receiving a bill by email have been given 10 per cent off of their bill. The discount was already reduced from 15 per cent last year.

Those who want to switch to a cheaper deal also face problems. Regulator Ofcom has already told firms they should tell customers when contracts come to an end, so people know when to look for a cheaper deal. At the moment, though, this rarely happens.

Trying to compare packages between the major providers is also nigh-on impossible. Research by Broadband Choices shows that the total cost of landline and broadband from some of the major providers is up to five times as much as the advertised price. 

And if you stay loyal to your provider, you're punished with even higher prices.

And not all customers can get all services. Virgin cables connect to only 13.6 million homes in the country. Some people can't get Sky because their property can't be fitted with a satellite dish. And even BT does not offer its superfast broadband to all homes across the country.

Once you've decided what to buy, there can be additional charges for the technology that helps you get your internet and TV service, such as routers and boxes.

Research by uSwitch has found that those who stick with their provider after their initial deal are paying £151 a year more than they should.

Homes hit by the great internet go slow 

Once you have broadband, it's likely it will be slower than you had hoped.

The speed and the amount of internet you can download are crucial to many households these days - particularly those who enjoy video games, and anyone who uses internet television services such as Netflix.

A survey by consumer association Which? found 90 per cent of consumers rate speed as an important factor when they picked an internet provider.

Despite this, Which? found that 15.4 million homes don't get the advertised speed. The figures are even worse in peak hours: it is estimated just 15 per cent are able to get the maximum advertised speed.

Overall, fewer than one-in-three households in towns and cities is capable of getting the maximum speed; in rural areas just 4 per cent of homes are able to.

Part of the reason for this go-slow is that the wires which provide the internet service aren't capable of delivering the highest speeds.

To get a top service you need fibre optic cables. But only a fifth of homes in the countryside are connected to these compared with three-quarters of those in urban areas.

And even where there are fibre optic cables, these often don't run straight to your front door. Many superfast cables run only to the exchange at the end of your road. From there, copper wires - which are much slower - run the signal to your house.

Many superfast cables run only to the exchange at the end of your road 

If fibre cables are laid right the way to your home, it's possible to get speeds of up to 330 Mb per second - that would mean an HD film could be downloaded in under 20 seconds. 

But if you just have copper wires running to your house, the maximum it would be theoretically possible to get is 80 Mb.

Yet despite providers boasting that they can produce these speeds, Ofcom research shows the typical speed achieved across the country is just 23 Mb.

Again, even this can be theoretical for homes in built-up areas where lots of households all want to use the internet at the same time.

So at peak times, typically at weekends and between 8pm and 10pm on weekday evenings, just one in 25 of TalkTalk's customers received the maximum advertised speed of 17 Mb during Which? testing.

A fifth of its customers achieved an average speed of only 5 Mb - half that of Ofcom's recommended minimum speed.

Sky, BT and Plusnet customers typically achieved speeds of 10 Mb during the research. And fewer than one in five of their customers managed to get the advertised speed.

Virgin Media offers a rare glimmer of hope to internet users who want to get the fastest speeds. Research found that 98 per cent of its customers get the advertised speed in off-peak hours, while more than half will get these speeds at peak times.

So how do the firms get away with advertising speeds which are just not achievable?

It is because internet providers need only to ensure 10 per cent of their customers can get a certain speed. Hit this target and they can boast that there speeds 'up to' that level.

The requirement on other sectors are much more onerous. For example, loan and credit card firms cannot advertise a rate unless it is available to at least 51 per cent of applicants.

Virgin has branded internet advertising rules 'outdated and misleading'.

Why complaints can be ignored 

While prices rise and consumers get frustrated by their plodding broadband speed, complaints are sky-high.

In June, Ofcom warned telecoms firms to improve service. In particular, it says people still find it too difficult to change provider and cancel contracts.

Ofcom data shows that some of the biggest firms are generating complaints which are way over the industry average of 16 per 100,000 customers.

TalkTalk received 27 complaints per 100,000 customers. BT and Plusnet received 22 and 20 complaints respectively. Virgin Media saw just seven complaints, and Sky had the fewest at just five for every 100,000 of its broadband customers.

But in August the regulator announced it would be investigating Sky over concerns that it was ignoring customers' cancellation requests or making it difficult for them to leave their contract.

The communications watchdog also introduced a strengthened code of practice on broadband speeds, allowing customers to exit a contract if speeds fall below acceptable levels.

Meanwhile, many providers say they are limited in how much they can improve their services because BT controls the network which runs all the wires - this is run by a BT-owned company called Openreach.

Rival internet providers either pay a fee to use Openreach equipment and run their service through that, or install their own equipment in Openreach exchanges and rent a copper line to run to customers' homes.

Sky is petitioning Ofcom to change this system, arguing that they rely on it to provide a service to customers and it is wrong that they have no control over it.

BT argues that disrupting the status quo would delay improvements. Meanwhile, as these big firms bicker, service continues to be disrupted for ordinary consumers.

A Virgin spokesman says: 'Virgin is the only widely available provider to consistently deliver its advertised speeds, let alone exceed them.

'This is because we have our own fibre-optic broadband network while other providers are reliant on BT's copper cable.'

A TalkTalk spokesman says: 'TalkTalk is the only provider to offer unlimited broadband as standard on every single package, with no hidden charges or download caps. We provide customers with a speed estimate before they sign a contract with us.'

A BT spokesman says: 'In common with the rest of the industry, BT's standard line rental has increased since 2008, but that stat only tells part of the story. We're very clear that customers should not rely on headline claims for broadband speeds but use the personal speed quote we give them at the point of sale, which is based on their own line.

'If they aren't happy with this personalised speed, they can decide not to buy from us. If they are happy with the speed, but find they don't achieve it, we allow them to end their contracts in line with the Ofcom code of practice.'

A Sky spokesman says: 'Our line rental price remains competitive and we continue to invest in our service. When customers sign up to broadband we estimate the speed they can expect, and they can cancel their broadband if we're unable to deliver a guaranteed minimum.'
